title: Arduino Basics - Quiz
description: Test your knowledge about Arduino basics such as #define, setup, loop, pinMode, and functions

questions.question: What does #define do in an Arduino program?
options: Replaces a word with a constant value
questions.explanation: #define replaces a word with a constant value before the program is compiled.

questions.question: Why is using #define useful?
options: It makes code easier to read and maintain
questions.explanation: Using #define avoids magic numbers and makes code clearer and easier to maintain.

questions.question: When does setup() run in an Arduino program?
questions.explanation: setup() runs only once at the beginning of the program.

questions.question: Which of the following is usually placed inside setup()?
questions.explanation: pinMode() and other initialization tasks are typically placed in setup().

questions.question: What makes loop() special in Arduino?
questions.explanation: loop() repeats continuously after setup() finishes.

questions.question: What happens when Arduino reaches the end of loop()?
options: It restarts loop() from the top
questions.explanation: After finishing loop(), Arduino automatically starts loop() again from the top.

questions.question: What does pinMode(RGB_RED, OUTPUT); mean?
questions.explanation: OUTPUT mode means the pin sends signals, like powering an LED.

questions.question: Which mode should be used in pinMode() to read a button?
questions.explanation: Buttons and sensors require INPUT mode to read their values.

questions.question: Why do we create the function setRGBColor()?
questions.explanation: setRGBColor() simplifies code by grouping three analogWrite() calls into one reusable function.

questions.question: What values does setRGBColor(red, green, blue) accept?
questions.explanation: Each color channel accepts a value from 0–255, controlling brightness.

questions.question: What is the range of values accepted by analogWrite()?
questions.explanation: analogWrite() accepts values from 0 to 255.

questions.question: What does analogWrite(RGB_GREEN, 0); do?
options: Turns the green LED fully off
Turns the green LED fully on
Sets green LED to half brightness
questions.explanation: A value of 0 means the LED is completely off.

questions.question: What does analogWrite(RGB_RED, 255); do?
options: Turns the red LED to full brightness
Turns the red LED to half brightness
questions.explanation: A value of 255 means the LED is at maximum brightness.

questions.question: What does analogRead(A0) return?
questions.explanation: analogRead() returns a value between 0 and 1023.

questions.question: If analogRead(A0) returns 1023, what does it mean?
questions.explanation: 1023 means the pin is reading maximum voltage, usually 5V.

questions.question: Which function pauses the program?
questions.explanation: delay() pauses the program for a given time in milliseconds.

questions.question: What does delay(1000); do?
questions.explanation: delay(1000); pauses for 1000 milliseconds, which is 1 second.

questions.question: If you want to pause for 5 seconds, what delay value should you use?
questions.explanation: 5 seconds equals 5000 milliseconds, so delay(5000); is used.

questions.question: Why might using too many delay() calls be a problem?
options: It blocks the Arduino from doing other tasks
questions.explanation: delay() stops everything else, so too many delays can block other tasks.

questions.question: Which function is used to declare whether a pin is input or output?
questions.explanation: pinMode() sets a pin as INPUT or OUTPUT before use.
